report_title: Indoor Sports Facilities Management Industry Report
executive_summary: The Indoor Sports Facilities Management industry endured steady growth during the beginning of the current period, prior to a steep decline in 2020 amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Operators manage indoor recreational sports facilities, which does not include bowling alleys and college facilities. Over the past five years, higher sports participation rates and growing public awareness of the link between physical activity and health led to an increase in demand for operators' services, as rising per capita disposable income expanded consumer spending. Nonetheless, the economic downturn due to the pandemic erased these gains, as temporary closures of establishments resulted in a sharp 31.2% decline in revenue in 2020.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: COVID-19 Pandemic Negatively Affects Consumer Activity, Harming Industry Stability
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Indoor sports facilities are heavily dependent on steady consumer activity, a trend that was severely disrupted during the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020 and dampened operators' core revenue streams.
Growth in per capita disposable income, consumer confidence and health awareness following the COVID-19 pandemic is expected to benefit the industry over the next five years.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Continuous emphasis on health and well-being will accelerate industry demand
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Consumers' propensity to maintain their health and improve their fitness levels will be a crucial driver of growth for the industry, especially among consumers with pre-existing conditions looking to stay in shape.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Economic recovery following COVID-19 pandemic strengthens consumer sentiment
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As the economy recovers following the COVID-19 pandemic and consumer confidence is restored, the industry is poised to capture a large share of pent-up demand from consumers across different age brackets and accelerate broader growth in sports participation.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Evolving demographic trends accelerate diverse revenue streams for the industry
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: A core development for the industry is the evolution of the United States population and demographic changes that will accelerate revenue and diversify the industry's customer base.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Diversification of activities offered by operators bodes well for customer interest
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Moving forward, indoor sports facilities operators will look to leverage the multitude of physical, leisure and recreational activities that can be hosted at their facilities.

industry_definition: Operators in this industry maintain and operate recreational indoor sports facilities. This report includes for-profit and nonprofit facilities that generate revenue through membership or admission fees. It excludes fitness centers that primarily provide exercise equipment and other indoor recreation facilities such as college facilities, bowling alleys and dance halls.

threats: Time spent on leisure and sports

key_trends: Volatile economic conditions dampen industry performance. As the COVID-19 pandemic damaged consumer sentiment and high inflationary pressures ate into consumers' disposable income, many core revenue streams declined.
Increased demand for health upkeep boosts industry recovery
Emphasis on sports participation fuels industry growth. As more consumers participate in sports, the industry will receive higher demand for its services.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: High Inflation Limits Fiscal Flexibility Among Consumers Aged 18 and Younger
demand_determinants.determinant_description: As team sports such as basketball and soccer maintain significant audiences among consumers under the age of 18, with the segment encompassing the largest revenue stream for the industry.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Higher Competition from Traditional Gyms Harms Demand Among Consumers Aged 18 to 35
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Most young adults continue to generate interest within team sports and see indoor sports facilities as an opportunity to work on their health and socialize at the same time.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Growing Fiscal Flexibility Boosts Demand Among Consumers Aged 35 to 49
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Although older adults have interest in team sports, it is less intense compared with younger adults, as they prefer more individual sports such as track and tennis.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Emphasis on Healthier Habits Enhances Demand Among Consumers Aged 50 and Older
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Baby boomers have been shrinking as a share of industry revenue over the past five years, with the COVID-19 pandemic forcing many older consumers to avoid indoor places and exercise outdoors or from home.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The general rules and regulations of the Federal Trade Commission and of other federal, state, provincial and local consumer protection agencies apply to franchising, advertising, sales and other trade practices.
Facilities are subject to numerous other types of federal, state and provincial regulations governing the sale, financing and collection of memberships.
Advertising of nutritional products is subject to regulation by one or more federal agencies.
During the COVID-19 pandemic, many facilities implemented strict social distancing measures and mask mandates to ensure safety.

basis_points.basis_title: Emphasis on customer service heightens internal competition
basis_points.basis_description: To ensure a facility can maximize consumer volume, they must have functioning machinery and high customer service to secure a wide swathe of customers.

basis_points.basis_title: Increasing appeal of gyms and fitness clubs exacerbates industry competition
basis_points.basis_description: The increasing appeal of individual gyms and fitness clubs provides consumers with various alternatives.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Localized demand for indoor sporting facilities dampens broader market concentration
concentration_points.concentration_description: Many of the indoor sports facilities operate within local regions and compete for niche customers.

concentration_points.concentration_title: High operating costs discourage large-scale consolidation
concentration_points.concentration_description: Indoor sports facilities are very prone to economic volatility and operate with consistently high operating costs.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Some of the other costs accrued by the industry include general administration, IT expenses, insurance, taxation and maintenance costs.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: The industry's primary expense is wage costs, making it more labor intensive.
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: There is a constant need for employees to facilitate adequate functioning of the facility.

FAQs.question: How well does your company market to consumers with limited leisure time?
FAQs.answer: Leisure time has fluctuated over the past five years, so time spent on activities that relate to indoor sports facilities have been impacted.

FAQs.question: Does seasonality affect sales for the products and services your company offers?
FAQs.answer: Seasonality is less critical than other recreational industries because all industry facilities are indoors.

FAQs.question: How does your company use location to add value and offer unique products and services to your consumers?
FAQs.answer: Location is one of the most critical factors affecting the operations of indoor facilities.

FAQs.question: Are your products and services well-rounded, to mitigate sudden changes in demand?
FAQs.answer: Indoor facilities have increased products and services through added amenities including food and cleaning services.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored lowering wage costs through part-time labor and automation via point-of-sale systems?
FAQs.answer: Wage costs have increased over the past five years as companies have increased value-add services requiring more labor.
